												 I purchased this game as part of the Saints Row Ultimate Franchise Pack, which was on sale at the time for about $18.  I can honestly say this game has left me completely satisfied with my purchase, and despite having bought the bundle at the beginning of the summer, and played every day, it was at least a month before I even opened Saints Row 3 for the first time, because I was having so much fun playing Saints Row 2, and there is simply that much to do.  With 233.8 hours on record as of my review, I still am only at about 95-97% completion on my first and only playthrough, because it was simply too much fun screwing around.  Even after finishing the story missions, of which there are more than enough to make the game worth buying all by itself, there was still so much to do.  The controls took a bit of getting used to, but only at first.  After a short while, any oddities control-wise felt completely natural, which is far from always the case when talking about ported titles.  The only thing I could recommend a controller for would be the driving/piloting.  While driving ground vehicles, the WASD keys don't quite give you the best experience, but they work perfectly fine for it.  The main complaint I had about the game in general were the flight controls, which were awkward at first, but even after getting used to the layout, which wasn't that strange, it still lacked the ability to make small adjustments without losing control, unless you practice a lot. (I practiced a lot though, and mostly was able to work around it.) I got so accustomed to the keybindings in this game that I actually changed most of my SR3 keybindings to match (where they were different at least) because I found I honestly missed many of the default keybindings where they had been changed.  Still, using a console controller for the air vehicles is probably your best option, if nothing else.  The graphics are far from amazing by current standards, but considering the time the game was made, they're perfectly solid, and the water still looks more real than watch dogs (you actually have a wake in a boat! HOW ADVANCED!! Sorry had to. considering I got this game in a huge bundle for only 18 dollars, I am not only satisfied, I would gladly have paid $18 dollars for this game alone, if I evaluated the value of the game solely on the amount of fun I had playing it.  All in all, I fully recommend this game and hope others enjoy it as much as I have.

												I’m glad I decided to play this game! The only reason I started playing it was because I finished Saints Row 4 and loved it, which made me want more. As it turns out Saints Row 2 feels like it hardly belongs in the same franchise as the fourth game. Volition have truly reinvented the franchise as they’ve gone from title to title, only keeping the characters and setting as they go. This explains why the people who loved the second game and wanted more of that tend to complain loudly about the third and fourth games. They’re just not the same. Personally I think reinventing and iterating are both equally valid approaches for a series to take. I like the variety, and you certainly can’t accuse them of retreading the same ground like I’ve seen some do with Rockstar and the GTA series.Saints Row 2 came out in 2008, and it feels like a game of its time. It might not seem like 2008 is that far back, but when you play games of that time they all feel old now, as does Saints Row 2. At that time I remember games journalists were talking about emergent gameplay instead of story, and it shows in Saints Row 2’s design. Compared to any major game released in 2013 this feels like complete chaos. Instead of the world acting like a virtual movie set with carefully staged combat, the game instead relies on world simulation systems and AI to act on its own. This approach makes it nearly impossible for a developer to tell a story during missions, because the minute to minute gameplay is completely unpredictable. Instead the designer only choreographs the action with commands like: Go there, kill that, chase that car, etc. Even during missions the world simulation present in the free exploration mode is in full effect. So when you take over areas of the map you’ll have friendly thugs spawn there. If a mission happens to take place there, or a car chase goes through neighborhoods controlled by your gang, groups of friendly thugs will spawn and rain bullets on your pursuers. If during a mission an enemy shoots a civilian standing near you, police will arrive on the scene and start fighting the enemy gangsters with you. The last time I saw this kind of three way combat break out spontaneously was in the Stalker games. I wish we had more games like this, especially on the next-gen consoles where the extra memory and power could allow much more elaborate world simulation. That would in some way fulfill “the point” of next-gen hardware. Making something you couldn’t do on 360/ps3, just like this game is something that couldn’t exist on PS2.Anyway, I had a great time blowing through this game. It’s messy, ugly, glitch, but it all comes together to create something special. One thing I was pleasantly surprised by was the quality of the cutscenes. In Saints Row 4 they were generally very high quality, but in a couple scenes I found the sound to be a bit crap. In Saints Row 2 the sound during cutscenes is phenomenal. It’s raw, violent and has about as much impact as you could hope to have. It fits perfectly with the story itself which in the “Brotherhood” missions turns into an ugly conflict where neither side appear noble or heroic in any way. It’s dark, gruesome and I was even shocked at one scene where the game made it abundantly clear that the player isn’t a hero anyone should aspire to be. So I finally get where the hype about Saints Row 2 has come from. If you know you’re a fan of slightly janky games with outstanding qualities you’ll probably like this. Those wanting a slick, modern, controlled experience should avoid it like the plague.

FUN-60%  FRUSTRATION-40%Saints Row 2 can be considered a good fun game for most parts but there are hiccups. Bad porting aside, the game revolves around just killing and destroying stuff all the time. It lacks variety in it's main missions which showed real promise. For argument's sake one can say the game is old and it's not fair be hard on it but there were games way before SR2's time that offered much more variety in missions. The story is not that compelling too. The story is all about you being a prick, going on a killing spree, eliminating other gangs that had taken over the city which the Saints once ruled. May be the charcter was meant to be that way - an arrogant a-hole, who knows?, I found the cockiness annoying. Be forewarned- Port issues like fps drops, crashes, loud cutscenes can get you♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off. Fps drops not so much but crashes are a little frequent, atleast once in 2 hours or so. To fix loud cutscene audio i had to fiddle around lowering windows volume level considerably and adjusting in-game sound sliders until i found a good balance between cutscene volume level and in-game volume level.Where the game makes you forget all of this is the Activities and Side Missions part. Its pure fun and can add to atleast half of your playtime. There are tons of activities like brawling, racing, pimping, trailblazing with an ATV, Heli-assault, Drug-trafficking, Insurance Fraud-my personal favourite much like goat simulator, Hitman targets etc. These side activities really make a difference and makes up for the lack of variety in the main missions. If they could've just put in a taste of these during the main missions then it could've been a much better experience overall. May be the core idea here was to offer a direct approach in the main storyline ie, eliminate your foes with guns blazing and chill out later doing these cool/varied activities to brush off the hollow approach or vice-versa. It leaves you with a mixed feeling in the end.        The graphics are decent considering its an old game. The music and voice acting is good though its a bummer you can't use custom mp3s for the radio. Driving, shooting etc are pretty good (I used a controller). Flying helicopters, biplanes etc feels terrific. Essentials: Set Custom Resolution Editor if you need one: http://blog.gib.me/2009/01/06/saints-row-2-resolution-editor/Gentlemen of the Row Mod (fixes a lot of stuff): http://idolninja.com/sr2.phpHigh Quality Radio Mod: https://www.saintsrowmods.com/forum/threads/high-quality-radio-mod.9515/Summary:Its not a bad game by any means but in my opinion it could've done much better in the storytelling department. Considering its an old game and that I had fun, I must say I came out satisfied eventhough it was a bad port. Fans of the series may swear by this game but if you are a newcomer and have played lot of newer similar titles like GTA V, then it may be wise to stick on to newer Saints Row titles. But who am I to say this? You may like SR2 or may not, it all depends on the type of gamer you are and what you expect out of the game. This review may best serve as a heads-up on what the game is about, and to me its a decent game best played if you have nothing else to play.  MY SCORE: 70/100

												As today marks 7 years since this account's creation, I figured it'd be appropriate to review the reason why it came to exist: the legendary Saints Row 2.After being introduced to the series through ♥♥♥♥ing around on friends' consoles, I didn't know what Steam was, who Valve were nor, amusingly, how PC specs worked; only that I wanted to play it as soon as possible. I didn't have a capable computer at the time and had only been able to play video games with mates, short of the countless hours spent in Age of Empires II and the like.So after buying the disc copy on a whim and, months later, finally getting the necessary PC upgrades, it was activated under something called a Steam account. I was ready to go and, at long last, introduced to Stilwater and the wonderful, seedy world of the 3rd Street Saints.Needless to say, it was just as good as everything I had hoped for. It’s funny, considering all the time that I’d spent leafing through the manual to check out all the insane, balls to the wall action on offer, I still had no idea that the PC version was one of the worst ports ever released. With little to compare it to at the time, you take what you can get and I loved every minute of SR2. Though it must be about five years now since last playing it, Johnny freakin' Gat, Dane Vogel, Aisha, Jane Valderama and the Freckle ♥♥♥♥♥'s ads over the radio are all still part of the many fond memories spent in the Row. The campaign itself is short and you can probably get through it in about 8-10 hours, though back when THQ and GameSpy were still active, co-op greatly extended the replay value. Throw in some hilarious cheats and the sandbox was literally bursting with stuff to do. In the years since, we've seen a significant departure from the GTA influence (and the charming borderline rip-off) of the original games alongside a vastly different industry, but they're no less enjoyable. In fact, Saints Row IV quite possibly stands as my personal favourite of the series and easily one of the best open-world games available. (The throwbacks are especially nostalgic. Remember that pin-up of Shaundi? The hospital escape with Gat? Skee ball and Loa Dust? Good times.) As I’ve already spent plenty of time talking about the good ol’ days, let’s pretend to focus on some relatively objective details quickly. To be clear, SR2 is not a perfect game; it’s not even a great game. Despite holding it in high regard for a time that’s long since passed, the criticisms raised in response to the awful bugs, non-existent optimisation and clear lack of QA testing are all perfectly valid. Thanks to the efforts of the small yet surprisingly dedicated community, a few restoration mods have appeared in recent years, namely the Gentlemen of the Row overhaul, but if you’re hesitant about spending the time to bring this train wreck up to its pulpy, cinematic brilliance, I’d recommend checking out something else. However, if leading the revival of the iconic Saints in an all-out, city-wide gang war, (full of dark humour and fantastic gameplay to boot), seems like your kind of game then look no further. Welcome back, Boss. We all have that one title that we’ve grown with; the game that we’ve spent countless hours in, losing sleep and friends as a result. Saints Row 2 happens to be one of these, and thus, even with all its flaws, it would be a crime not to recommend. Here's to gaming.

I'll start off by saying that the pc port is absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ Even on the best hardware around this game will not stay at a stable 60 fps on high settings. But I still prefer the pc version over the console version. On the xbox 360 and ps3 the game often goes below 30 fps and crashes from time to time. At least the pc version never crashed when I played it and it never went below 30 fps on my pc. Also the online doesn't work anymore because gamespy closed down, so if you want to play with a friend you need to use hamachi or evolve and run a lan game.With that out of the way, let the real review begin.It's one of the most enjoyable games I ever played. It may even be one of my favorite games of all times for many reasons. But the #1 reason has to be the humor and the near perfect balance of semi-serious crime drama and wacky comedy. I found myself laughing almost all the way trough the story. If I like humor so much then why don't I think that SR3 and 4 are better? Well the fun moments are so balanced out that it works that much better. In SR4 it bombards you with funny things but you get too used to it. In SR2 the funny moments are balanced out so that you don't get used to things being whacky and you'll apreciate the fun/whacky moments more for it.There also is the crazy amount of custumization in the game. You can decide at what angle you tilt your hat. I don't think I need to say more than that.The gameplay is pretty standard. It plays like a modern version of the ps2 gta games. But the minigames are amazing. You can join a wrestling club, spray poop on houses to devalue the land,  pretend to get hurt to claim insurance, steal hookers from their pimps, ride a burning quad though the city and more. I'm not kidding. These are actual minigames. There are also standard ones like racing, being a hitman, stealing certain cars, etc. I do hate the fact that you need to complete mini games to unlock story missions but I probably wouldn't have played them otherwise.The music is also pretty good. I really like the 80's radio station. There are cd shops in the city where you can buy music to make a mic tape with to listen to in your car on the way to your next burning quad time trial. (I especially love Out of Touch and Down Under).The entire story is playable in co-op and you will see your own charcter in the cutscenes (not the host's character).
